questions.text: A 3 year old boy has a history of progressive developmental delay, ataxia, seizures and in appropriate laughter since infancy. The child has a normal karyotype of 46XY but DNA analysis shows that he has inherited both of his number 15 chromosomes from his father. These findings are most likely to be indicative of which of the following genetic mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C

Genomic imprinting disorder

Child has features of angelman syndrome and DNA analysis shows uniparental disomy

questions.text: Porcine cardiac valves transplanted to humans is which type of graft
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C

Xeno graft

  • ALLOGRAFT – genetically non identical individual of same species
  • AUTOGRAFT- within the same individual
  • XENOGRAFT- diff species
  • ISOGRAFT- genetically identical – monozygotic identical twins

questions.text: A child is diagnosed to have an anemia which is commonly inherited. There is no history of any such disease in any of the family members of either parent including themselves. What is the % risk of next child to be born with same disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : B

25

if there is no history of genetic disease in family but child has a genetic disease means it is mostly autosomal recessive and both the parents are carriers, thus 25% is the right answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation and its correct interpretation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer :  C

FISH Amplification

questions.text: Which of the following is correct order of steps of inflammation ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D

Margination , rolling , adhesion , diapedesis

questions.text:
Match the following 

A) Burkitt lymphoma                                        1) t (14;18)
B)  Follicular lymphoma                                   2) t(2;5)
C) Mantle cell lymphoma                                 3) t(8;14)
D) Anaplastic large cell lymphoma                 4) t(11;14)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

 Burkitt lymphoma – t(8;14)
 follicular lymphoma – t(14;18)
 mantle cell lymphoma- t(11;14)
 Anaplastic large cell lymphoma- t(2;5)

questions.text:
Match the following –
1. Melanin                                          i) Rhodanine
2. Copper                                           ii) Masson trichrome
3. Collagen                                        iii) Von kossa
4. Calcium                                         iv) Masson fontana
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D

1- iv,2-i ,3- ii,4- iii

questions.text: A 55-year male presents with bone pain for last 3 years. Peripheral blood smear shows 22% plasma cells which are lambda restricted. Serum calcium is elevated and IgG is 32g/l. which of the following is diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D

Plasma cell leukemia

Peripheral blood plasma cells (monoclonal) more than 20% is diagnostic feature of plasma cell leukemia

questions.text: Storage temperature of RBC , platelet and FFP are-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

RBC 2-6℃ , platelet 20-24℃  , FFP -25℃

questions.text: All of the following are features of irreversible injury except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

Blebs formation

questions.text: In blood preservative CPD SAGM which of the following increases shelf life by increasing ATP production?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C

Adenine

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of the events in the cell cycle.

1.Cyclin D – CDK 4
2.Cyclin A- CDK 2
3.Cyclin B – CDK 1
4.Cyclin E- CDK 2
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D

1-4-2-3

questions.text: A patient diagnosed of Acute Myeloid leukemia now presents with epistaxis, multiple ecchymotic patches. Coagulation profile of the patient shows elevated BT, CT, PT, aPTT and TT. Which of the following cytogenetic changes are expected in blasts?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C

t (15;17). 

AML patient is having DIC, frequently seen with AML M3
Acute Promyelocytic leukaemia, which shows 15;17 translocation

questions.text:
Match the following-
1. Adhesion                      i) Selectins
2. Rolling                          ii) PECAM-1
3. Chemotaxis                 iii) Integrins
4. Transmigration           iv) LTB4
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B

1-iii, 2-i, 3-iv,4-ii

questions.text: What type of necrosis is seen on cross section of left ventricle of heart of a patient who has died of myocardial infraction ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C

Coagulative necrosis

questions.text: In a laboratory exercise for medical students, an unknown compound is studied. The students are informed that the compound is derived from endothelium and is inhibited by aspirin. The students further demonstrate that the compound is potent vasodilator and platelet anti- aggregant, the most likely substance is which of the following mediators?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B

 PGI2. 

It is primarily synthesized by endothelium being a product od cyclooxygenase pathway of arachidonic acid it is inhibited by aspirin. PGI2 is a potent vasodilator, platelet anti-aggregant in contrast with thrombaxin A2 (TXA2) which is also inhibited by aspirin but TXA2 is platet aggregant and vasoconstrictor. The other components (LTB4 &LXA4) are derived from lipoxygenase pathway hence not inhibited by aspirin.

questions.text: A 28 yr old man goes to the doctor for an annual physical examination. On rectal examination, masses are palpated. The patient is referred for a colonoscopy, which reveals adenomatous polyps located diffusely throughout the colon. When asked about his family history, the patient states that his father passed away from colon cancer. A diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis is suspected & the patient asks how he got this. Which of the following is the inheritance pattern of this condition ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C

Autosomal dominant

 FAP is an autosomal dominant caused by germline mutation in APC gene

choices.text: They are always increased in inflammation.
Transferrin is an acute phase reactant.

questions.text: True about acute phase reactants are all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

Acute phase reactants can increase (posi- tive APR) or decrease ( negative APR).

questions.text: BRAF mutations are seen in which of the following neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

Hairy cell leukemia

BRAF mutations are seen in hairy cell leukemia, the drug of choice against this mutation is dab- rafenib.

BRAF – HCL , LCH , PAP THYROID

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B

CD 20+ CD5+ CD23+

questions.text: Most common type of chromosome seen in humans is?
questions.solution:

Submetacentric.

questions.text: In iron excess condition Protein, A is secreted by liver which causes down regulation protein B in the gut. Protein A and B are respectively?

Correct Answer: C

Hepcidin, ferroportin

questions.text: A 35-year female presents with easy fatigue, blood smear is as shown in the image. Serum ferritin is 10ng/ml, TLC 11000, platelet count 400000. What is diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B

IDA. Microcytic + low serum ferritin = IDA

questions.text: Sequence of nuclear changes in irreversible cell injury-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C

pyknosis, karyorrhexis, karyolysis

questions.text: A 62 year old female is suffering from renal failure and is on hemodialysis since last 8 years. She developed carpal tunnel syndrome. Which of the following will be associated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D

ABeta2 microglobulin


A beta2macroglobulin – seen in hemodialysis patient 
A beta – Alzheimers disease
AL – Multiple myeloma
ATTR – senile systemic amyloidosis

questions.text: All are pro apoptotic molecules except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  C

BCL 2

BCL2, BCL XL and MCL 1 are anti apoptotic molecules. Rest are all pro apoptotic molecules.

questions.text: Banding technique used for identification of Chromosome Y is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D

Q-banding

C banding Is for Centromeres, G is routine banding technique

questions.text: Diagnosis based on following karyotype.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C

Patau Syndrome

TRISOMY 13 – PATAU SYNDROME

questions.text: ADAMTS13 deficiency in plasma is seen in –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura

ADAMTS 13 is a enzyme which cleaves the multimers of vWF on the endothelium, deficiency of this causes TTP.

questions.text: A 9-month old boy has had history of multiple bouts of otitis, sinusitis, bronchitis, oral candidiasis and multiple viral infections. Cessation of recurrent infection follows a successful bone marrow transplant. Likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  D. 

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency. 

SCID is X linked SCID – in which IL7 receptor signalling is defective , both T & B cell function is gone , IL-15 receptor signalling is also ineffective
 Autosomal Recessive SCID – is mostly due to Adenosine deaminase deficiency

questions.text: A 20 year old female is diagnosed with granulosa cell tumor of ovary. Which of the following biomarkers would be most useful for the follow up of the patient ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  D

 INHIBIN 

 CA 19-9 – PANCREATIC CA 
CA 125= serous ovarian ca
NSE = neuroendocrine tumor

questions.text: True about Lyonisation are all except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In 1961, Lyon outlined the idea of X-inactivation, now commonly known as the Lyon hypothesis. It states that (1) only one of the X chromosomes is genetically active, (2) the other X of either maternal or paternal origin undergoes heteropyknosis and is rendered inactive, (3) inactivation of either the maternal or paternal X occurs at random among all the cells of the blastocyst on or about day 5.5 of embryonic life. The inactive X known as the Barr body, or X chromatin. The molecular basis of X inactivation involves a unique gene called XIST, initiates a gene-silencing process by chromatin modification and DNA methylation. The XIST allele is switched off in the active X.

choices.text: Calcification in normal tissue seen in hyperparathyroidism
Calcification in destroyed tissue with hypercalcemia
Calcification in destroyed tissue with normal calcium level in blood

questions.text: Dystrophic calcification means –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Calcification in destroyed tissue with normal calcium level in blood

questions.text: Retinoblastomas arising in the context of germ line mutations not only may be bilateral , but also may be associated with –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

TRILATERAL RETINOBLASTOMA = B/L RB + PINEALOBLASTOMA

questions.text: A 2 year old child presents with scattered permeating lesions in the skull. Electron microscopy has revealed following image. All are positive in this condition except–
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Electron microscopy is showing tennis racket appearance which is birbeck granules , seen in LCH 

Markers – CD1a , S-100, CD207 (langerin) 

LCH is not a B cell neoplasm , so CD19 is negative

choices.text: Inactivation of DNA mismatch repair gene
Mutation of RB tumor suppressor gene

questions.text: Hereditary non polyposis colon cancer is caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

It is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by the increased incidence of colon cancer and extraintestinal cancer particularly the ovarian and endometrial cancer.

Mutation in DNA repair genes

Colon cancers in these patients affect right side of colon

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP)

Autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance

Mutation of adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene present on the long arm of chromosome 5q (5q21).

Subtypes of FAP- Classic FAP syndrome

There should be a minimum of 100 polyps to make a diagnosis of this syndrome. Most of the adenomatous polyps are tubular polyps

Attenuated FAP syndrome

The patient has a lower number of adenomatous polyps (around 30) which are located in proximal colon. Gardener syndrome- lntestinal polyps + epidermal cysts + fibromatosis + osteomas (of the mandible, long bones and skull) 

Turcot syndrome- polyps + CNS tumors (medulloblastoma and gliomas)

questions.text: A new described neurological disorder is found to affect multiple members in the family over 3 generations. In the first generation which consisted of two sisters and one brother all were found to be affected. In the second generation all children of first generation sisters were affected but children of sons were spared. In the third generation all children of second generation women were affected but not the children of second generation men. The mode of inheritance is -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mitochondrial. Looking at the history closely that only disease has been transmitted from mothers to all children and father to none of children, hence the answer

questions.text: A 42 year old patient presents with cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy.He is also complaining of cough and significant weightloss since the past 4 months.Excision biopsy of the cervical lymph node is shown in the given image.These large atypical cells are positive for CD 15, CD30 and negative for CD 3 and CD 45. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Image shows lacunar type RS cells seen in nodular sclerosis type of HL which are positive for CD15 , CD30 and PAX5

questions.text: Which factor deficiency will not affect coagulation invivo but will affect invitro?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

12

In vivo we can bypass factor 12 and activate factor 11 thus deficiency doesn’t affect the coagulation invivo

i. Not inhibited by aspirin

ii. Chemotaxis
